Suppose the bee occupies the point $(a,b,c).$ If the die shows $A^+$, then the bee moves to the point $(a+1,b,c)$ and if the die shows $A^-,$ then the bee moves to the point $(a-1,b,c).$ Analogous moves are made with the other four outcomes. Suppose the bee starts at the point $(0,0,0)$ and the die is rolled four times. What is the probability that the bee traverses four distinct edges of some unit cube?

$\textbf{(A) }\frac{1}{54}\qquad\textbf{(B) }\frac{7}{54}\qquad\textbf{(C) }\frac{1}{6}\qquad\textbf{(D) }\frac{5}{18}\qquad\textbf{(E) }\frac{2}{5}$

ost_step.3: There are two ways to reach the state $(\pm 1, 0, 0)$: either roll an odd number of $A$s followed by $B^+$, $B^-$, or no $B$, or vice versa. The same applies to $(0, \pm 1, 0)$ and $(0, 0, \pm 1)$. The remaining state is reached when rolling only $C$s.
ost_step.4: Using symmetry, the probability of reaching any of the states $(\pm 1, 0, 0),$ $(0, \pm 1, 0),$ and $(0, 0, \pm 1)$ is equal. Call this probability $p$.

direct_answer.text: To calculate p, observe that only $C$s lead to state $(0, 0, 0)$, so the probability of reaching this state is equal to the probability of rolling only $C$s, which is $4/6\times 4/6\times 4/6 \times 4/6 = 256/1296$. This also implies that the probability of reaching one of the other states is $1-256/1296 = 1040/1296$. For the probability of reaching one of those states, use the complement rule. Either an even number of $A$s are rolled, which happens with probability $3/6\times 3/6 \times 3/6 \times 3/6 = 81/1296$, or an odd number of $A$s are rolled, which happens with probability $3/6\times 3/6 \times 3/6 \times 3/6 \times 3/6 = 243/1296$. Therefore, the probability of reaching any of the desired states is $1040/1296 - 324/1296 = 716/1296$. Divide this value by 8 (since there are 8 possible states), yielding $89/162$. The answer is C.
